panels.description: Heat map showing the typical time before a job starts and whether the number of jobs in that time bucket are increasing or decreasing.
panels.title: Startup Duration

panels.description: Heat map showing the typical time to complete a job and whether the number of jobs in that time bucket are increasing or decreasing.
panels.title: Job Execution

panels.description: The number of runners registered for processing queued jobs
panels.title: Registered Runners

panels.description: Number of registered runners that do not have assigned jobs.
panels.title: Idle Runners

panels.description: The number of jobs assigned to the scale set.  The threshold is triggered with the number of assigned jobs exceeds the number of desired runners. This indicates that not all jobs will have an available runner.
panels.title: Assigned Jobs

panels.description: The number of workflow jobs currently executing
panels.title: Running Jobs

panels.description: The number of runners in a failed state. These runners are typically misconfigured and count against the scale set's maximum limit.
panels.title: Failed Runners

panels.description: The number of active scale set listeners
panels.title: Listeners

panels.description: Number of runner pods that are waiting to be created. When this number exceeds the number of pods Kubernetes reports as Waiting, it indicate cluster performance issues.
panels.title: Pending Runners

panels.description: Number of runners desired by the scale set
panels.title: Desired Runners

panels.description: Number of runner pods in a running state
panels.title: Active Runners

panels.description: The number of containers that are reporting that they were terminated by an out-of-memory condition (OOMK.iller)
panels.title: Out of Memory

panels.description: The peak memory used by a container in a given scale set's namespace.
panels.title: Peak Container Memory

panels.description: The sum of the reads and writes occurring within the runner namespace.
panels.title: Container I/O

panels.description: The Kubernetes-reported pod status.
panels.title: Container Pod Status

panels.description: The average time required for a reconciliation request to be processed. This reflects the time required for the controller to process a single request to modify a Kubernetes resource.
panels.title: Reconcile Time

panels.description: The average time a queued reconciliation request spends waiting to be processed.
panels.title: Workqueue Queue Duration

panels.description: Errors indicate that controller has not achieved a desired state and is requesting Kubernetes to queue another request for reconciliation. Ideally, this number remains close to zero. An increasing number can indicate resource contention or delays processing API server requests.
panels.title: Reconciliation Errors

panels.description: The number of reconcile requests that are waiting to be processed by the controller. A growing queue depth can indicate that the Kubernetes API Server or the controller does not have enough resources. This can lead to pods taking longer to be deleted or started.
panels.title: Queue Depth

panels.description: The number of workers that are currently being used to process reconcile requests. Increasing this number can reduce the work queue duration, but each new worker adds a small amount of time due to context switching.
panels.title: Active Workers

panels.description: The number of calls to the API server
panels.title: API Calls

panels.description: The time required by Prometheus to read and process metrics. Long scrape times can delay metrics updates or lead to metrics loss. Increasing time often indicates issues with metrics cardinality or cluster resources.
panels.title: Scrape Duration

list.description: The name of the runner scale set
list.label: Scale Set
list.name: Scaleset
